comments.commentBody:
A lot of words and effort are spent ruminating on the working philosophy of the libertarians and their extremist, fundamentalist manifestation.

How about one take a step back and see the real picture.

The working philosophy is merely a propulsion module that will be jettisoned once the aims of an elite group of individuals are achieved. The real issue, that nobody wants to discuss, or do anything about, is the amount power a small group of individuals is able to wield, to influence and effect political, economic and social outcomes using tools such as certain working philosophies, myth or not.
Eli has a couple of SB rings, of course.....BUT he is indeed mediocre to poor in his play at times this season. Please do not deny he is one of the problems.

Victim she might be, but instead of walking away, she married him too.

It's bad enough for Ray Rice to show young boys and men a (negative) "role model" that with such abusive behavior, and it's as if somehow it's excusable for his behavior just because you've got some "talent" (in Rice's case, sports). It's equal bad for Janay Rice to become yet another (negative) "role model" that an abused woman should stand by her hand, no matter what.

Theirs is a textbook case of abusive relationship. As bystanders, the society at large should send strong signal not only to Ray Rice that his behavior is inexcusable and not tolerated, and we should equally send strong signal to Janay Rice that her behavior to endorse and even encourage abused victims to just suck it up is the wrong thing to do. Neither of their behavior should be endorsed or encouraged.
Why is victim in quotes?

Oh my goodness! There is no excuse for punching your wife and dragging her out of an elevator! NONE! So sad that the "victim" is having to do the PR work to prop up her husband's image. I guess not loosing the big money is worth it?
Really? I'd rather feel safe on a smaller yearly income. Really, there is no excuse and there should be zero tolerance.

It's too about the chain of abuse through the generations in his family that lead him to not even be aware his behavior was not OK. The roots of abuse are abuse. It needs to stop at one generation.One may hope that Mr. Rice learn that the "training" to abuse can be broken and should be broken. One may hope that Ms (now) Rice also learns that co-dependency also needs treatment. Too much to hope? Perhaps since abusers are seen as unchangeable by "therapists"; another lamentable group think attitude.

Underinsurance has not been caused by the Affordable Care Act. The Commonwealth Fund survey actually concludes that the ACA has helped prevent underinsurance among the 7 million who enrolled via exchanges and who have incomes below 250% of the Federal Poverty Level. The survey also concluded that the ACA helped reduce underinsurance by slowing the rate of increase in medical costs. That also helped the 150 million employees and their families covered by employer sponsored health plans.

As the author quoted, underinsurance increased 80% in the 7 years prior to passage of ACA. And employers continue to increase cost sharing and, therefore, underinsurance. Employers are only required to offer plans that cover 60% if the cost of coverage or cost employees no more than 9.5% of their income. Most employers have continued and report they plan to continue to shift costs to employees.

So, don't blame the ACA Mr. Carroll.
Sad, carefully orchestrated. Ms. Rice and her mother ("Candy") are chasing the money. Ray is the money earner. More diamonds, please.
Football players might hit back!
Are you crazy?  She was the aggressor?  He outweighs her by 340 pounds.  nothing she did to him could have injured him, especially since she'd been drinking.  OMG.
But at age 28, his playing days are numbered. He and she are both in a hurry before the opportunity to make the big bucks evaporates. Then where will their marriage be?

It is hard to believe that these interviews are anything but staged and serve a limited purpose....resuscitating the career of Ray Rice.  I sometimes wonder why these "interviews" even take place.  If Ray Rice is really a "good guy" who made a stupid mistake, it will be borne out in is behavior over the next ten or twenty years.

Uhm, in other words, you're providing proof that a man may indeed hit a woman only once and then never again.  Seems to be what happened in your family, right?  Nevertheless, almost everyone posting seems to believe that it is an impossibility--even you begin by expressing doubt.  Certainly statistics indicate that it's unlikely, but I don't understand why everyone is so absolutely positive about what really has happened in this particular relationship and why everyone is so willing to in essence to label Janay a liar.
Given how much she stands to lose financially, her defense of him is no surprise.
This article was about Janay Rice and her situation.  there is zero comparison to what went on in Missouri.  Don't mix your analogies, metaphors, or situations, Joe, in Iowa.

Worse yet, they weren't married when it happened, so her ability to get at any of his assets through litigation would have required a full blown civil suit (like the suit against OJ), rather than a division of assets in a divorce proceeding.

Let's not forget that the most dangerous time for a woman in an abusive relationship is when she attempts to leave it. Imagine the danger of leaving when his career might be dependent on her defending him.

Meanwhile, perhaps the publicity of it all (including doing what she could to make him 'a good guy' who had 'just' had too much to drink) will save her life, rather than have excused his behavior and encouraged the free fist reaction to stress.

If what you say is true, "she allowed herself to be pimped" then isn't the PR geeks of the NFL and Rice the pimps?

It's disturbing that you only speak disparaging towards her, but not Rice.

What a pathetic display of desperation. That she allowed herself to be pimped this way by the PR geeks of the NFL and her husband's legal team speaks volumes for the fact that women are still possessions of their wealthier (and more visible) husbands.

She should have left him the moment it happened. However, she loves the lifestyle and it would have been very hard for her to move on. Being his wife with all the perks it brings is a much better way to life, than being his ex with a huge alimony.
Are they not one and the same?

The unknown is how biological factors influence our perception of reality. If our minds are just calculating machines designed to accumulate and use information to interpret reality, then, perhaps, 'lower level' Darwinian principles might well be the 'rules engine' that's used to organize the information, and drive the calculator.

One thing that we know for sure is that morality is in the perception of the beholder! There may be a common denominator, an average, and a mean, but it is certainly not an absolute!

The underlying issue is not the health care law but the profit lust of the health care industry. People end up with $5,000 bills for a few stitches in the ER and at the other end if the spectrum, may pay ten times more for major surgery than in any other developed country.

A quick wholesale conversion to single payer would probably collapse the system but a good start would be to allow those age 50 to buy into Medicare, with its more globally comparable reimbursement rates.

If the "business model" of the health care providers doesn't change, our entire economy could be dragged down.

Exactly. Why is this person allowed to be judged only by the deluded and fear-stricken Ms Rice? He is a menace to society and he committed a crime-- right in front of all of us. Why is he not in prison?

Nor does it mean that Ray Rice committed a crime, if it is true that Janay struck Ray Rice first and his striking her was a response to that attack. That is a threshold question, which, as far as I know, hasn't been answered. For if Janay attacked first, then Ray's striking her would have been legal and moral self defense.

I am going to discover the answer to this threshold question.

Just because Janay Rice is, for whatever reason, deluded and bent on defending this animal, does not mean he is not animal, that he did not commit a crime, and that he does not deserve to be put on trial for those crimes.

Hundreds of millions of people saw what he did. He is a danger to society at large. Why is he not brought to justice?

$$$$$$$$$ and $$$$$$$$ and more $$$$$$$$$$ !!!!!!!!!!!! what a way to make a living......getting knocked out by your boyfriend and then marrying him and then stumpping for him on national tv!!!! she is beyond discusting!!!!
Does one have to get drunk at a bar?
So I guess we should let all drunk drivers off without charge too, if we can follow your logic.  If you get wasted and commit an assault, no harm, no foul?

First, we don't know if they were drunk or not. Second, what's the relevancy of their inebriation? Prosecute or expose the placed that served them….what about Rice. Shouldn't he be prosecuted for the crime he committed?

I wouldn't give him a break - no way.

They were evidently drunk. That seems to happen. Give them a break.

Prosecute or expose the (over) servers at the bars, and the owners of the establishment.
This is all about $$$. If she wants peace she can stop giving interviews.

He wasn't losing his ability to provide for his family - I'm pretty sure he would have plenty of other job opportunities, none of which should be in the NFL where he is idolized by people of all ages and demographics. Witnessing his actions and the lack of repercussions demonstrates to those fans that domestic abuse is somehow acceptable and condoned. Also, your attempt is spin this incident into an enlightening moment for domestic violence is absolutely deplorable - there is absolutely no silver lining with this incident. Regardless of the conversation concerning domestic violence, the NFL and its players should always hold themselves to a level that is worthy of the respect and admiration of fans around the nation and to do otherwise would be irresponsible. In the end, however, neither will change because they don't need to.

CJ - you would only like to say "SHAME ON YOU…". When do you think you might say it because right now your only stating what you would like to do.

She wasn't slapped in the face; he punched her and dragged her…

Do you have empathy for her?

Why are you victim blaming?

She's a battered woman. What she is doing now fits into exactly what happens without outside help. Denial is whats going on and it fits the profile of the battered. Please do not blame the victum, that is
the easy thing to do. She is the victim and that is a fact.

First I would like to say SHAME ON YOU! Mrs Rice

Your husband's behavior reminded me of a famous caricature Neanderthal men pulling women by the hair in a cave.

His action is not excusable and have showed a great disservice to young women across the nation and the world that it's ok to be slapped in the face by your husband.

I have no sympathy for you.
Must be low self-esteem.

I have totally lost my respect for football. Between concussions, cheating scandals, growth hormones, exam cheating at colleges, rape, assult, and child abuse, I feel like I have been knocked out.

I was amazed when two men said in the NYTimes comments that they were no longer making football there sport and would no longer watch. That's it! That is what I am going to do, and when a game is on in a family members house, I will bring this up tactfully and ask what they think. One person at a time adds up.

Thank you guys!
